I designed the 12-bit rainbow palette for use in my data visualisations. It consists of twelve colours chosen with consideration for how we perceive hue, chroma, and luminance. The palette uses a 12-bit colour depth, so each colour requires only four characters when specified as a hexadecimal colour code in a CSS or SVG file. For more details, see https://iamkate.com/data/12-bit-rainbow/

#WebDeb #WebDevelopment

As you might have seen in the last boost, I've started a new server directory site to help people sign up on Mastodon and the Fediverse:

➡️ https://fedi.garden

If you want to follow the project, its account is at:

➡️ @FediGarden

Reasons for making this directory:

-It will list both Mastodon and non-Mastodon servers.
-It has a maximum size, megaservers aren't listed.
-It's manually curated and has safety/reliability requirements.

As far as I know, no one else is doing this.

We now have 3 LGTMs on view transitions, meaning it can start the journey to Chrome stable without a flag! https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/AJJiH6Pjr50?pli=1

title: Ivory for Mastodon Review: Tapbots Reborn

last_post.content:
Ivory by Tapbots is launching today.

This app marks the beginning of a new era for Mastodon clients on Apple platforms. It raises the bar in this category, but there’s still work to be done.

I reviewed Tweetbot 1.0 on MacStories in 2011; 12 years later, here is my review of Ivory 1.0:

Ivory for Mastodon Review: Tapbots Reborn https://www.macstories.net/reviews/ivory-for-mastodon-review-tapbots-reborn/
I really enjoyed reading: Case Study: lynnandtonic.com 2022 refresh https://lynnandtonic.com/thoughts/entries/case-study-2022-refresh/

Soft launching a curated directory of Fediverse servers to join:

➡️ https://fedi.garden

To be listed, a site has to:

-Obey the Mastodon Covenant (but doesn't have to be running Mastodon)

-Have fewer than 50,000 registered members

-Be open for public registration, either directly or through requests

Unlike https://joinmastodon.org, this site will accept non-Mastodon instances, and has an upper size limit

Unlike https://instances.social etc this site is curated.

(1/2)

title: Tools such as ChatGPT threaten transparent science; here are our ground rules for their use

last_post.content:
Nature sets the right ground rules for using GPT-like tools for research papers.

1. No co-authorship since AI cannot take responsibility

2. Must acknowledge use

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00191-1

You should read @Mer__edith's thread on all this,¹ and it's worth remembering what @signalapp does and does not do.

Signal does not protect you from:
• an untrustworthy chat partner
• a compromised device
• corporate device management
• your device's Operating System

Signal does protect you from:
• a hack of the Signal servers
• a subpoena of the Signal servers
• the wire between you and the Signal servers
• the employees at Signal

¹ https://mastodon.world/@Mer__edith/109751701529562752

#Genuary26 #Genuary

Day 26: My kid could have done that

For this prompt I implemented the sinuous meander patterns of Chappell. They resemble the bug-eyed, multi-legged monsters that my kid used to draw when he was little, all spirals and curves with countless appendages.

https://doi.org/10.1080/17513472.2015.1092859

In a big chunk of the call, we discuss why a full-fledged OSS app like @elk is beneficial to the @vite, @nuxt, and Vue ecosystems.

Improvements to Vite plugins, Vue libs, and Nuxt modules (even new ones created from the App needs). And huge amount of DX and UX data to further enhance them and test new ideas in the future.

Some of the most active maintainers of plugins and modules have integrated their libs themselves into the project. Diving into the code base of Elk could help you learn more about these tools and how they play together.

https://youtu.be/A1MuI1CzvQo

title: Revealed: how US transition to electric cars threatens environmental havoc

last_post.content:
Fantastic new study by the great Thea Riofrancos et al

This research is a very, very positive and important contribution to showing the benefits of active and public transport, and a sign that climate action can be designed to be beneficial, with minimal environmental impacts.

There are plenty of people who trade in absolutism in climate solutions - who make an active effort to ensure we avoid alternative futures that ease the pressures of this massive change.

This paper is a nice corrective against them.

https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/jan/24/us-electric-vehicles-lithium-consequences-research

title: The Value Of Owning More Books Than You’ll Ever Read

last_post.content:
Do you own far more books than you'll ever read?

<raises hand>

Here's a useful way to think about it: All those books are what Nassim Nicholas Taleb calls an "antilibrary"

They are the whitespace around your knowledge

They keep you humble -- sure, you know stuff, but behold all the things you *don't* know!

Or, as I put it ... they're a form of "intellectual orienteering"

My essay: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994

A "friend" link if you're not a Medium subscriber: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994?sk=d9575f6411ee9d9a756e2b59ab1e9b2e

i just let rip a new piece of writing:

a year-long observation on trends in the peer-to-peer space, namely the appearance of companies building platforms on top. outlined are a few of these platform companies, accompanied by questions regarding expected futures, as well as a small essay on the importance of community infrastructure

🍐 https://cblgh.org/p2p-commercialization/

title: Webb Unveils Dark Side of Pre-stellar Ice Chemistry

last_post.content:
Surprisingly not a still from a sci-fi movie, this new #JWST image shows us the central portion of the star-forming Chamaeleon I molecular cloud.

The cold, wispy cloud material (blue, center) is illuminated in the infrared by the glow of the young, outflowing protostar Ced 110 IRS 4 (orange, upper left). The ices in the cloud absorb some of the light of background stars (orange dots), allowing us to detect them.

Read more: https://webbtelescope.org/contents/news-releases/2023/news-2023-106

1/
#astrdon #astronomy #space

Ivory is out! By far and away my favorite Mastodon app.

Before @ivory, Mastodon felt like a Twitter clone that I wasn’t really “getting”, bouncing between apps and not finding any that fit me.

With Ivory, Mastodon became not only a drop-in replacement for Twitter for me, but an upgrade that’s actually so much better than Twitter that I don’t think about it at all anymore.

I immediately subscribed to the highest Ivory plan. They deserve our support!

https://apps.apple.com/us/app/ivory-for-mastodon-by-tapbots/id6444602274?l=en

My project right now is #BikeHopper, an open-source directions app for transit+bikes.

https://github.com/bikehopper/bikehopper-ui

It uses #OpenStreetMap and a modified version of GraphHopper.

Two main benefits over other trip planning apps:
1. Bike-on-bus, bike-on-train etc. options
2. Tries really hard to find low-stress routes, avoiding main roads

title: Working from home saves employees 2 hours a week in commute time, and they’re spending it in ways CEOs don’t expect

last_post.content:
Study of 27 countries finds the average daily time savings for remote work is 72 min per person. Workers allocate 40% of the saved time to their jobs, 11% to caregiving, and 34% to leisure.
https://fortune.com/2023/01/24/worker-productivity-spend-commute-time-working/

title: It's time to focus on information warfare's hard questions

"Overemphasis on social media manipulation risks both distracting from and reinforcing two notions in need of greater scrutiny: first, that platforms are neutral conduits, co-equal victims with their users of external forces largely beyond their own control; second, and far more importantly, that online influence operations necessarily work in the first place.”

Research papers increasingly refer to websites like GitHub for code, which may be a problem...

About 20% of preprints referred to GitHub in 2021. Yet, these web pages are often not archived, jeopardizing their long-term availability.

"The growing use of Git Hosting Platforms in scholarly publications points to an urgent and growing need for dedicated efforts to archive their holdings in order to preserve research code"

via https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2208.04895
#OpenScience #OpenSource @academicchatter

A collection of the papers for the @ICAHDQ 2022 preconference “What Comes After Disinformation Studies” is now online, published by the Center for Information, Technology, and Public Life. It critiques the current disinformation discourse.

Involved in the preconference and special issue were @kreissdaniel, Meredith Clark, @alicetiara, Sylvain Parasie, Rachel Kuo, Elaine Schnabel, @shannimcg, and yours truly.

https://citap.pubpub.org/what-comes-after-disinformation

#polcomm #commodon #journodon

Ok, so.

Tweets look really good when you send them in Messages on iOS/macOS. Mastodon posts… don’t. So I built a little tool that makes them much nicer to look at:

https://mstdn.link

Add ?to={any Mastodon post URL} to the end of that domain and when you send it to a friend, you get the nice looking preview. Of course the page makes it easy to paste a URL in. And there’s a Shortcut to make it even easier on iOS or macOS.

title: 5 Things We Learned About Journal Peer Review in 2022 - Absolutely Maybe

last_post.content:
5 things we learned about journal peer review in 2022 – my annual roundup of research on peer review.

It was a bumper year for randomized trials in peer review – 5 of them! We can't usually count on even 1.

title: What the hell is REST, Anyway?

last_post.content:
if anyone's wondering, when i say "representational state transfer" i mean the "how do i invisibly thread state between rpc calls" thing and when i say "hypermedia apis" i mean "how can a method return a service to a client" stuff—not the random slapfighting about verbs and urls that passes for engineering

and if you want examples of the former, i did write a tumblr post a while back

https://programmingisterrible.com/post/181841346708/what-the-hell-is-rest-anyway

title: WSJ News Exclusive | BuzzFeed to Use ChatGPT Creator OpenAI to Help Create Some of Its Content

last_post.content:
Meanwhile, as mentioned, businesses are not just writing software to be dependent on OpenAI's propreitary APIs but retooling entire business models around it. Once they flocked to Facebook, then seemed confused when suddenly the audience they'd built up was Facebook's audience now and they had nothing except what Facebook gave them. When their relationship with OpenAI someday flips the same way, they'll be just as confused how it got to that point.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/buzzfeed-to-use-chatgpt-creator-openai-to-help-create-some-of-its-content-11674752660

MusicLM: Generating Music From Text

Presents MusicLM, a model for generating high-fidelity music from text. MusicLM generates music at 24 kHz that remains consistent over several minutes.

proj: https://google-research.github.io/seanet/musiclm/examples/
abs: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11325
data: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/googleai/musiccaps
